qas.question: The current continents were formerly known as what continent?
Which oregenies followed the Nevadan in the Cretaceous?
South America was formerly which continent?
The rifting in the Cretaceous had what result on the oceans?
Antarctica was a part of what supercontinent?

plausible_answers.text: the Cretaceous, the late Paleozoic-early Mesozoic

qas.question: During what periods did Pangaea come together?
Which oregenies followed the Nevaden in the early Mesozoic?
What supercontinent stayed intact during the Cretaceous?

context: During <b5_0>the Cretaceous, the late Paleozoic-early Mesozoic<b5_0/> supercontinent of <a0_0>Pangaea<a0_0/> completed its breakup into present day continents, although their positions were substantially different at the time. As the Atlantic Ocean widened, the convergent-margin orogenies that had begun during the Jurassic continued in the North American Cordillera, as the Nevadan orogeny was followed by the <a1_0><b6_0>Sevier and Laramide<b6_0/><a1_0/> orogenies. Though Gondwana was still intact in the beginning of the Cretaceous, <a2_0><a4_0><b7_0>Gondwana<b7_0/><a4_0/><a2_0/> itself broke up as South America, Antarctica and Australia rifted away from Africa (though India and Madagascar remained attached to each other); thus, the South Atlantic and Indian Oceans were newly formed. Such active <b8_0>rifting<b8_0/> lifted great undersea mountain chains along the welts, <a3_0>raising eustatic sea levels<a3_0/> worldwide.
